I'm a cologne snob and wanted to inform you you have some flaws in your methodology. Firstly, colognes usually consist of notes that evaporate at different rates. The smell of a good fragrance evolves as you wear it. So spraying it on and having her immediately smell it doesn't mean she likes or hates the fragrance as a whole it likely means she likes the top notes.

Secondly, colognes are affected by temperature. So a cologne that's delightful in the winter might be horrid in the summer. Thusly your application of the cologne will affect the fragrance as well. It's best to apply weak colognes to warmer areas of the body and stronger fragrances to cooler areas of the body.

Lastly, I hope she decided on Creed Aventus... Because it's the best.... Science will back me up lol

How I pick my perfumes and toiletries is based on what I smell like in the morning. Mainly sweet and sandalwoodish with a bit of corriander seed, so I buy things that smell like that. As they wear off one by one they mix with my natural smell and enhance it.
Flowery tones turn sour on me, and those ones which smell like gin that I love just disappear completely.
So that's my 2c, see what you smell like when you're clean but haven't showered for 12 hours or so, and get smells that work with that.

That might be bad for "heavy" smells so during summer I get a "lighter", "fresher" one. If you want to stress the memory part, you can use it with physical activities or summer vacations. The other idea is that to create a truly unique smell, you might want to mix colognes. You can also do it in a variety of ways. I usually have a "base" one and I mix when there is an "event" so it is only a subtle change

00:53 - But keep in mind. Smell does trigger memory but if you expose someone to it "consistently" the memory trigger will wear off, so to speak.
This is to say that no matter how strong the feeling triggered is (either by smell or a song or what else),  or how strong the trigger itself is, you can't hold someone on an ecstatic feeling forever. Sort of like when you've heard a song you like a million times.
This is not exact, but for this case I believe it holds.

Your own pheromones will interact with the cologne, and also the woman's tainted sense of smell (for example, we are born naturally repelled by the pheromones of our own family members).  Point being, smells vary for everybody and each person will interpret the smell of a same cologne differently.
